citations.narrative:
Four common marmosets were found dead in their enclosure on 23-June-2025. The enclosure that the primates were
housed in was a tall glass structure with glass skylights on a covered wooden boardwalk. The temperatures were
abnormally high for in the area for consecutive days. According to weatherunderground.com the max temperature for 22-
June-2025 was 87 degrees Fahrenheit and the max temperature for 23-June-2025 was 89 degrees Fahrenheit. The
enclosure did not have additional ventilation or methods for cooling. The primates were noted to have been
eating/drinking and acting normal on 22-June-2025. However, the following morning the animals were found deceased in
their enclosure. The necropsy submission form submitted by the Attending Veterinarian noted that the animals were found
dead on the morning of 23-June-2025 with evidence of bleeding from the nose and mouth and that it was suspected to be
a heat related death. The licensee stated that the animals have been previously housed indoors in a temperature-
controlled environment and that they were introduced to their current enclosure in early May.
Animals that are exposed to climatic conditions that they are not adequately acclimated to can result in adverse health
effects, including death.
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal’s health or well-being, appropriate measures must be taken to
alleviate the impact of those conditions. An animal may never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity,
and time that is detrimental to the animal’s health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal’s age,
species, breed, overall health status, and acclimation. Correct by, 11-July-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(e)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Four common marmosets were found dead in their enclosure on 23-June-2025. The enclosure that the primates were 
housed in was a tall glass structure with glass skylights on a covered wooden boardwalk. The temperatures were 
abnormally high for in the area for consecutive days. According to weatherunderground.com the max temperature for 22-
June-2025 was 87 degrees Fahrenheit and the max temperature for 23-June-2025 was 89 degrees Fahrenheit. The 
enclosure did not have additional ventilation or methods for cooling. The primates were noted to have been 
eating/drinking and acting normal on 22-June-2025. However, the following morning the animals were found deceased in 
their enclosure. The necropsy submission form submitted by the Attending Veterinarian noted that the animals were found 
dead on the morning of 23-June-2025 with evidence of bleeding from the nose and mouth and that it was suspected to be 
a heat related death. The licensee stated that the animals have been previously housed indoors in a temperature-
controlled environment and that they were introduced to their current enclosure in early May. 
 
Animals that are exposed to climatic conditions that they are not adequately acclimated to can result in adverse health 
effects, including death.  
 
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal’s health or well-being, appropriate measures must be taken to 
alleviate the impact of those conditions. An animal may never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity, 
and time that is detrimental to the animal’s health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal’s age, 
species, breed, overall health status, and acclimation. Correct by, 11-July-2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
